item.title: India Ink: India Begins World’s Largest Democratic Exercise
item.description: After weeks of politicians hurling insults at one another and making booming speeches across India, the world’s largest democratic elections began in a remote corner of India on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: A woman preparing to cast her vote inside a polling booth in Dhekiajuli in the Tezpur constituency of Assam, on Monday.

item.title: India Ink: Bharatiya Janata Party Emphasizes Infrastructure and Jobs in Manifesto
item.description: The party focused on what it called the five T’s: tradition, talent, technology, tourism and trade.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: Narendra Modi, right, prime ministerial candidate of the Bharatiya Janata Party, along with Rajnath Singh, center, president of the B.J.P. and Lal Krishna Advani, a senior leader of the party, with copies of the party manifesto in New Delhi on Monday.

item.title: Center-Left Candidate, as Expected, Wins Big in Costa Rica
item.description: Luis Guillermo Solís won a landslide presidential victory after his opponent abandoned the contest.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: DealBook: Credit Suisse Is Said to Be Facing Double-Barreled Inquiries
item.description: As Credit Suisse negotiates with the Justice Department over its liability for involvement in tax shelters, New York State has opened its own inquiry.
item.dc:creator: By BEN PROTESS and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON
item.media:description: Brady Dougan, chief executive of Credit Suisse, at a Senate panel earlier this year.

item.title: In Testimony, Pistorius Calls Shooting a Mistake
item.description: Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star who is accused of murdering his girlfriend, said he thought he was shooting an intruder and that he was “simply trying to protect” her.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius and Reeva Steenkamp in Johannesburg in February 2013.

item.title: Protesters in Ukraine’s East Call On Putin to Send Troops
item.description: Pro-Russian demonstrators occupying a government building in Donetsk also demanded a referendum on seceding from Ukraine, hours after a Ukrainian officer was killed in Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Pro-Russian activists set up a barricade at a regional Ukrainian Security Service building in Donetsk on Monday.

item.title: Hagel Tours Chinese Aircraft Carrier
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel is visiting China amid tit-for-tat maneuvering and territorial disputes between China and its East Asian neighbors.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Genocide Commemorations Begin in Rwanda, With Curtailed French Role
item.description: French officials said the justice minister would not attend the events after President Paul Kagame of Rwanda accused Paris of “political preparation” in the 1994 killings.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: People gathered inside a church on Sunday before the start of a national mourning period commemorating the 20th anniversary of the country’s genocide.

item.title: Viktor Orban Wins a Second Term in Hungary
item.description: The conservative prime minister received a strong endorsement from voters, but the radical right-wing Jobbik party also gained strength.
item.dc:creator: By PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 3 Lawyers Say They Were Tortured After Protesting ‘Black Jail’
item.description: A lawyer says he and other lawyers were tortured in detention in Jiansanjiang in Heilongjiang Province, where they tried to draw attention to the incarceration of Falun Gong adherents.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Jet Search Team Says Signals Are ‘Consistent’ With Black Boxes
item.description: The chief of the team hunting for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 on Monday called the lead “probably the best information that we have had.”
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: This Chinese patrol ship, the Haixun 01, reported Saturday that an underwater sensor had picked up a promising signal.

item.title: Israelis and Palestinians Ask U.S. Envoy for New Meeting
item.description: The request came after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel would take “unilateral steps” in response to the Palestinians’ move last week to join international conventions.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Governing Party Figure Makes Overture in Taiwan Standoff
item.description: Speaker Wang Jin-pyng has told demonstrators occupying Taiwan’s legislature that he agrees that a law offering greater oversight of agreements with China should be approved before negotiations resume on a stalled trade pact with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Wang Jin-pyng, legislative speaker in Taiwan, greeting protesters.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Sweeping Graves the Party Way
item.description: This year, the state is exhorting people to include the veneration of Communist leaders and revolutionary heroes as part of the holiday that traditionally commemorates a family’s departed members.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A woman repainted the characters on the tomb of a deceased relative at the Babaoshan cemetery in Beijing on Saturday, the beginning of the Qingming Festival.

item.title: Thomas Polgar, C.I.A. Officer, Dies at 91; Helped Lead U.S. Evacuation of Saigon
item.description: Mr. Polgar, the C.I.A.’s Saigon station chief, urged Americans, in a final dispatch, to learn from their defeat in Vietnam.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

item.title: Search Crews Detect Signals They Say May Be From Missing Malaysian Jet
item.description: The chief of the Australian team coordinating the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 said Monday that it had detected “transmissions consistent with” flight recorders, possibly from the missing jet.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:description: This Chinese patrol ship, the Haixun 01, reported Saturday that an underwater sensor had picked up a promising signal.

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 7
item.description: What you need to know about India’s elections on Monday: the northeastern states of Tripura and Assam are the first regions to vote and the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party readies its manifesto.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Libyan Rebels Vow Gradual End to Oil Standoff
item.description: The agreement reached with the government allows some ports to reopen immediately, both sides confirmed, while others will resume functions within four weeks.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Snowden to Receive Truth-Telling Prize
item.description: Edward J. Snowden and the journalist Laura Poitras, who helped him disclose the documents on government surveillance, will receive a Ridenhour prize.
item.dc:creator: By NOAM COHEN

item.title: Facing His Torturer as Spain Confronts Its Past
item.description: José María Galante says he was tortured by an infamous enforcer of the Franco dictatorship in the 1970s. He is seeking to prosecute the man in an Argentine court.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: José María Galante said he was tortured after being arrested for his anti-Franco protest activities. "I agree with the idea of reconciliation," Mr. Galante said. "But you just can’t turn the page."

item.title: Surge of Violence Across Syria Kills Over Two Dozen
item.description: An explosion killed antigovernment fighters preparing a car bomb in the central city of Homs, and shells struck central areas of Damascus, the capital.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and MOHAMMED GHANNAM
item.media:description: A boy was rescued in Aleppo on Sunday after an attack with what activists said were barrel bombs dropped by government forces.

item.title: Costa Rica Set for Lopsided Victory
item.description: The victory of Luis Guillermo Solís, a history professor, who sought to win one million votes in the presidential election, seemed likely on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: A Star Candidate’s Support for Secession Undercuts Quebec’s Governing Party
item.description: The desire by Pierre Karl Péladeau, a media mogul running in provincial elections, for Quebec to secede from Canada appears to have destroyed his party’s hopes for victory.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Pierre Karl Péladeau, left, with Pauline Marois, right, leader of Parti Québécois, at a campaign stop in Quebec City on Sunday.

item.title: France Curtails Role at Genocide Services After Rwanda Leader Casts Blame
item.description: French officials said they would not attend the commemoration of the 1994 massacres after President Paul Kagame of Rwanda accused France of “political preparation” in the killings.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: People gathered inside a church on Sunday before the start of a national mourning period commemorating the 20th anniversary of the country’s genocide.

item.title: Early Tallies Indicating Afghan Vote a Success
item.description: Election officials said the vote count indicated that about 60 percent of the 12 million eligible voters had cast ballots.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker at the Independent Election Commission in Kabul took inventory of ballot boxes on Sunday. More than seven million ballots had been counted.
